addressleaf.section:
1594
3 May
M.
of Instructions for M
r
Bodleigh sent to
e States Generall
.

page.lettertext:
fol.185r
An Instrucc
o
n for Thomas Bodeleie, being sent
to the States
and
consell of estate
, and
e Comte Maurice
, for
thes thinges heare after following./.
Yowe shall use all expedic
o
n to deliver o
r
l
re
s to the
Generall Estates, or in theire absence to the Counsell of
Estate, wheareby wee have require them to geve yowe Aw-
dience, and to yelde
unto
to such Request
as yowe shall
make unto them on o
r
behalf: for the reasons followinge./.
Yowe shall declare unto them that the Spaniardes w
ch
are in
Bretaegne
have of late taken and fortefied a spetiall place
in the Haven of
Brest
, wheareby if they shall not be
speedelie empeached theie shall be Commaunders of that
Haven, beinge the most principall place wheareby they
Brest.
shall beco
m
Lordes and Commaunders of all the trade by
Sea westward either towardes
Bourdeaux
,
Rochell
,
Spayne
, or other places
westw
r
d
whatsoever, and theareby shall
also empeache and intercept all manner of Merchantes
passing from the [Est] towardes the west as all men of
knowledg and understanding of the situac
o
n of that haven
be
y
g
o
of
e best hav
e
s in [.] and so
neare to the streight betwixt
England
&
France
maye
vearie well Consider, and finde most necessary to be in the
beginning w
th
speed w
th
stood: for w
ch
cawse yowe shall
lett them knowe that wee have cawsed the said fortificac
o
ns
so begann by the Spaniards to be vewed, and the meanes
also discovered howe w
th
convenient force by sea & w
th
men to enter uppon the land, the same Enterprise of
fol.185v
the Spaniard maie be (if it be taken in hand speede
ly
either defeated, or made frustrate for w
ch
purpose wee
[.]
determined to send certaine shippinge thither, w
th
a nomber
[of]
men to attempt this
s
rvice, and for the more Expedic
o
n besides
some good nombers otherwise levied and provided w
th
in o
r
Realme, wee require the States to yeld sum succo
r
also
accord
y
g as is by speciall c
o
tract coven
a
ted
o
ther
te
by shippinge on theire part to Accompanie o
rs
, bicawse
[.]
the spanyard
have allredy armed certen shipp
and do use them [.]
our cost
of Engl
a
d and
e
t
of fr
a
ce to
w
d
e [lowet
] end of
e
gl
a
d
wher they have allredy tak
e
s
o
e of our subject
shipp
and besyde
t we und
r
stand
that ther by report
understand
by report that the Spaniardes doe meane to bring
into that Haven, sum newe forces of shippinge, w
ch
they
are preparinge newelie in Spaine, wholie to possesse the said
Harborough, beinge hable to harborowe
[.]
& hold above
a thowsand shippes of the greatest burden, and the greater
nomber of shippinge that they will yeld unto us, they shall
not onelie thearein greatlie Content us, but further that
w
ch
shall be profitable for them, and theire generall state
w
ch
cannot be but damnefied and endangered, considering
the mainten
n
ce of the state of thes Cuntries consisteth uppon
the free trade of Navigac
o
n unto the west partes thorowgh
o
r
Narrowe Seas: And this Aide of theirs, wee require to
be speedelie geven, and to be sent towardes
portesmouth
o
r
Plimmowth
, or
sum other westerlye port
of o
r
Realme, wheare they shall
have knowledge howe to meete w
th
o
r
Navye, w
ch
wee
have ordered speedelie to repaire towardes the sayd hav
e
of Brest:/ Secondly yowe shall lett them knowe
that wee requier to have such forces of o
r
subject
as be theare in o
r
pay to be speedelye browght from
fol.186r
thence to the Sea side to be shipped there and browght
to joine w
th
other o
r
forces levied and putt in order to
goe by Sea towardes the said
pt
port of Brest, for
Conducc
o
n of whome, wee have sent
S
r
Thomas
Baskerville
Knight to take the Generall charge of the
said nombers, and to bring them from thence by Sea,
to whome wee require the states to geve all reasonable
Commission for the safe passadge of him, and the
said Companies from the places wheare he shall finde
them unto the sea side
and that he maie have their power to take up [& hire] sufficient shipping in
Zeland
and
may be sufficient for the transportac
o
n of the sayd nombers upp
o
resonable [hyre] of
e [same]
./ And thowgh wee did
readelie yeld of late at the request of
e States
authoritie to cawse to be levied a thowsand five
Hundred soldiers w
th
in o
r
Realme, w
ch
weare sent
over thither by
S
r
Francis Veer
, and did also direct
to be sent
thither
to theire service under the Comte
Maurice other nombers, w
ch
before have
s
rved in
Normandy
and s
u
m also owt of
Flusshinge
and
Brill
& other
places, Yet wee did at the same time yeld thes
succo
rs
to them uppon Condic
o
n
and not oth
r
wise
that if yt showld happen
that wee showld have Cawse geven us by any Accedents
followinge to have the use and
s
rvice of thes o
r
people
theie showld uppon o
r
request retorne
fr
o
th
e
ce
to o
r
s
rvice
in anie place that wee showld commaund th
e
: And
therefore althowgh wee doe imagin they will be
loathe to forbeare the
s
rvice of thes men at this
fol.186v
time, bicaws of theire purpose by the defence of
Couverden
to recover the towne of
Groninghen
, a matter
cannot denie but maie be benefitiall unto them, yet
nothinge comparable in comm
o
n benefitt to the defeating
of this purpose of the Spaniard for the possessinge of
Brest: And the matter towchinge us soe neare as yt doth
wee cannot forbeare to seeke to have the Aide of o
r
owne
People,
nor
beinge
bye nature principally
as naturall subject
bownd to
s
rve
us before anie others: Wheareuppon yowe shall ernestlye
require them that they will geve order to all such that be
o
r
naturall borne Subjectes
now
and ther
s
v
y
g in band
maie be licensed to retorne
under the charge of the said S
r
Thomas Baskerville:
And if they shall object that the xv
C
w
ch
weare newly
levied by S
r
Francis Veere, are in theire paie, and have
been levied at theire charges, yet yowe shall saye
that wee thinke, consideringe the great debtes they doe
owe us, and that they never did yeld us anie benefitt
in monie or otherwise towardes the recompence of o
r
excessive charges thes manie yeres, they may forbeare
that charge, and if otherwise they will not freelye
yeld yt unto us, as s
u
m token of theire good will
wee shall be content, that such sommes of monye as
have been defraied by them of theire levie, and theire
wages theare maie be accompted as a portion of that
debt w
ch
they owe us, wheareof wee shall acquite
fol.187r
them. And bicawse wee thinke they will bee
hardlie induced heareunto,
for these xv
C
levyed at ther ch
r
ges
wee are contented that
upp
o
n the peremptory refusall hereof. for the yeldinge
to us of the
s
rvice of thes 1500. soe newlye levied.
Yowe shall precisely require of them that the
rest of o
r
Companies
be
y
g footem
e
that were from
Ostend
and
other places towardes theire
s
rvice, beinge in o
r
pay
maie be retorned: addinge that yowe will ad
v
tize
us of such reasons as they shall alledge for the
Staie of the others, givinge them su
m
hope that if they
will geve su
m
Aide of Shippinge,
accord
y
g to the c
o
tract
and geve expe-
dic
o
n for the retorninge of o
r
said nombers, beinge nowe
in their
s
rvice and in o
r
paie, Wee maye bee
the better contented w
th
theire manner of Awnsweres
But in noe wise yowe shall Accept of them any
Arguments or Awnsweares for the delaie of the
sendinge awaie of thes o
r
men
t ar in our paye, wheras
we do not meane to have any of our horsem
e
, to be revoked fr
o
thence.
And if it shall soe happen
t
ey will as heretofore
ey have
[.]
and in termes not to commaund
the comminge awaie of o
r
People
by theire Com
on
but shall
yeld to suffer them, than y
o
shall geve S
r
Francis Veere Know-
ledge of o
r
Pleisure for the
reduction of them from
thence, as yowe shall
prescribe unto him, for
w
ch
purpose yowe shall
have o
r
letter to him to
follow your direction
It
m
. Bicawse wee take yt that thes o
r
people are at
this present in the field towardes
Freeseland
under
the Commaundment of Comte Maurice, as generall
of the Armie of the States, Yowe shall have o
r
letters also of Creditt unto him,
to
whome yowe shal
either by yo
r
letters, or by yo
r
self, if conveniently
yowe maye repaire to the Campe, impart thes former
fol.187v
reasons heare before expressed, to be shewed to the States
for the havinge of
the
s
rvice of
o
r
people from thence
to this
s
rvice above expressed: And if yowe shall finde
it difficult to have the
s
rvice of the 1500. newelye
levied under the charge of S
r
Francis Veere, then yowe shall
lett the said S
r
Francis understand that wee are contented
that he shall continue theare w
th
them, and that he shall
use all the expedic
o
n he ca
n
, to retorne from thence under
the charge of S
r
Thomas Baskerville all the rest of the
Companies that are in o
r
paie: And for the charg
of theire reducc
o
n from thence and theire embarquinge
wee have geven order howe S
r
Thomas Baskerville
shall be furnished w
th
monie for the same purpose
And assone as yowe have obtained this o
r
request
consideringe wee understand that yowe have cawse
for yo
r
owne privatt busines to retorne hither, wee
are content yowe shall so doe, not dowbting but
yowe will employe yo
r
self to the uttermost to
obtaine asmuch of the
[.]
o
r
request
as possiblye
